dialogues.text: Hunts what?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Why--uh--animals, I should think.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh. Is that how he met Mark? Big-game hunting?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh--very big.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, if you're planning to marry him on my money, you're will not have a lunatic in the family. You and Mark are q me to cope with. Furthermore, when Alexander comes tonigh to him seriously about you. As your guardian, he should the kind of company you're keeping.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (quavering) You mean Boopie's coming here? Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Have you any objection to my seeing my lawyer? He's comin going to spend the night--and we'll settle this tomorrow. Her gaze fixes off-scene with astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David crawling through a hedge on his hands and knees aft

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: They react.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (aghast) Susan! We just can't have that man around!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: But, Auntie, he's only playing with George.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well, he's not going to play with George any longer. (calls peremptorily) George!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David crawling after George. The dog stops as Aunt Elizab heard again.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: George! Come here! This minute! George starts out of scene toward the voice. David grabs falls face down, missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Aunt Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Keep that man away from me, Susan. And mark my words, you either! You can push Providence just so far. George enters and she snatches him up in her arms and mar the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and David are sitting on the bank of a stream compl Susan is happy because she has succeeded in keeping David David is unhappy because she has succeeded in keeping him

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (sighing deeply and stretching out with her arms under he Oh--how quiet it is! Isn't it nice, David--just to be qui this way? Without a lot of people talking to us, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (staring glumly ahead of him) I can't think how he could have found a place where we di dug up practically twenty-six acres.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (with sweet reasonableness Now, David, everything's going to be all right. The bone' somewhere. George knows where. There's no point in our di George. But we can't have George because Aunt Elizabeth w of the house. (her tone changes) Wouldn't it be nice if we could just sit here forever an

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (glumly) But she has to let him out of the house sometime.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I always say that people don't have time to fall in love what could be nicer than just spending months and months acquainted-- with somebody, of course, that you like--and fall in love with? She rolls over and looks pensively at David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (hopelessly) Of course it's just possible that he didn't bring it outd

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You're not even willing to relax for a minute, are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (looking around at her bitterly Relax? Do you realize that I've telephoned my fiancee twi my marriage?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes. That's too bad. It must be terrible for a girl to re bone is more important than she is.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (violently) I haven't told her I've lost the intercostal clavicle! I It would be too great a shock to her!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't tell her I'd lost it, David---I'd just tel mislaid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you would.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Now I would suggest that you tell her that you'll be marr the same time. That will give you a week here. We're sure week.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, Susan, stop suggesting things!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (hurt) All right, David. I was only trying to help. They sit bolt upright as the scream of the panther is hea stable. Susan jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Baby! We haven't fed him!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (bitterly) If it weren't for my fossil, I'd feed him George.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (frantically as another scream is heard) If Aunt Elizabeth hears that-- my goose is cooked! She plunges off toward the stable and David follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside Box Stall -- David and Susan enter, leaving the do them. Susan pats the panther while David unwraps the pack bought at Westlake, which he has taken from the stolen ca crouches over the meat there is a low growl from the doo escaped the stern eye of Aunt Elizabeth and is spying as

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It's George! Grab him!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You grab him. You know him better.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That's why I won't grab him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (advancing on George) Keep that panther back. We can't lose George--yet.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Mark said he likes dogs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mark probably meant he eats dogs. He pounces on George in the dim light and goes out of the Susan following.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE BOX STALL
dialogues.text: -- David is hugging George firmly as Susan latches the do on the panther.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: He must like you. He hasn't growled since you picked him

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (bitterly) He can't. His mouth is full of my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David has changed back into his own clothes except for h on a fresh shirt and looks quite respectable again. He is telephone in the midst of an agitated conversation with M agitation arising largely from Susan's jerking at his elb

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But, Alice dear, I can't get in! I've been unavoidably de

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (jerking at his elbow) Tell her at the same time next week.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (putting his hand over the mouthpiece) Susan, will you go away?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (tugging at his elbow) But, David, it might take a week.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (into phone) What, dear? What did you say? ...Yes, dear, I know it's u There is a blast from the other end of the wire.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (jerking at his sleeve) Don't be afraid of her, David. Say something funny.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (goaded beyond control, fairly shouts into phone as the b I might as well tell you, Alice, --I've lost the intercos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a piercing scream from the receiver and he turn his ear with an agonized expression. Susan jerks the rece hand, puts it in the drawer and shuts the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (aghast as he indicates the drawer) But you can't just leave Alice there!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Who can't? David jerks open the drawer and takes out the receiver. H into the transmitter.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Alice! Answer me! Alice! Susan crowds her face into the transmitter and speaks in of an operator.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: When you hear the signal, the time will be exactly seven half. And she picks up a paper cutter and smacks a brass bowl, a loud gonglike note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice in a dead faint at the other end of the wire. [Scene Details]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT on front door. The doorbell is ringing. Mrs. Go door to disclose Major Horace Applegate, a well-dressed m or fifty. In the driveway, through the door, we see a tax scene.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: I am Major Applegate. Mrs. Random asked me for dinner. Wi if she still wants me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Elizabeth peers over Mrs. Gogarty's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is that you, Horace? Come in.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (entering) Well, well, well, Elizabeth! How are you?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (as CAMERA FOLLOWS them into the living room) I'm a nervous wreck, as you very well know. I'm always a What I need is absolute peace and quiet and I never get i me all my life I've been searching for absolute peace and always found exactly the opposite. Maybe that's what come in my family. It does seem hard. They run into Susan, who comes out of the guest bedroom, been helping David telephone.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Susan, I want you to meet a very dear friend of mine--Maj (as Susan offers her hand) He wants me to finance a most thrilling expedition and he go along.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I don't approve of expeditions. How do you do, Major Appl

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That needn't bother you. You're not going.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I don't think you should go either, Aunt Elizabeth. (to Applegate) She's really in very delicate health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a nervous laugh) Oh--really, Elizabeth? You-- you didn't tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (with a snort) I'm no such thing! I'm in perfect health--except that I'm wreck. David, a bit ill at ease, enters from the guest bedroom. on finding himself confronting a stranger -- Applegate. A looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I want you to meet Mr. Bone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID AND APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (extending their hands and speaking simultaneously) How do you do, Mr. Bone!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (losing patience with his paranoia, points a finger at Da You are Mr. Bone. This is Major Applegate.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (laughing uneasily) Oh yes. Yes. Quite. I'm Applegate.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But there must be some mistake --

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh no, there isn't! I've known Horace Applegate for twent take him away!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (with the sweet manner of a keeper) Come, Mr. Bone. We'll go for a nice little walk before di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David goes out in an utter daze. Applegate looks after h

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: What a pity! Such a nice-looking young man.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Conversation may be a little difficult at dinner, Horace. having a nervous breakdown. Talk to him about big game hu big game hunter, too. He can't talk sensibly about anythi

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Elizabeth. I can talk for days on that subject. D You'll find conversation flowing very freely once I start out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gogarty enters like a man who is in search of a bottle, w to the door of the box stall where Baby is, unlatches it walks past Baby in the dim light, reaches up to a rafter bottle, goes out with the bottle, leaving the door unlatc sits down on a box and uncorks his bottle. He takes a swi nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Elizabeth, Major Applegate, David and Susan are seat Conversation is slightly impeded because David will not l but George, who lies on the floor well within view. Mrs. already served soup to David, Susan and Aunt Elizabeth. N through pantry door, bears down upon Major Applegate.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat as she places the soup before him) Have you ever been in Arabia, Mr. Bone? Mrs. Gogarty marches back to the kitchen. David, engross makes no response and Applegate once more clears his thro again.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: I say, Mr. Bone, have you ever been -- in Arabia?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (abruptly, without taking his eyes off George) No.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (dogged) I suppose you've -- spent most of your time in Africa?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. Why should I? Applegate looks helplessly at Aunt Elizabeth, who makes a washing her hands of the whole business.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Tibet?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (desperately) Malay Peninsula? George gets up and wanders in a leisurely fashion through David rises abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Applegate follows David's exit with his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think IT hit it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (with a snort) Do you think it's worth it?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (quickly) He was horribly clawed by a tiger in the Malay States. He talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Oh, I see... Don't worry, Elizabeth. I'll draw him out. Through another door George comes into the room, David st him. George flops down. David resumes his seat and his so keeping his eyes fixed on George.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (tipping David off) I've just been telling Major Applegate that you were badl Malay Peninsula.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've never been in the Malay Peninsula. This throws them all for a loss.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: What type of gun do you use in hunting tigers? Again George is on the loose. David rises.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (muttering)  Excuse me. All watch as David stalks out after George.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Really, Susan, imagine giving a dinner party, with your h like Hamlet's father all through the meal! It's unthinkab

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (dreamily) Isn't he sweet! Did you ever see such shoulders!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gogarty seated on the box and taking another drink. Baby the stall and is padding silently toward him. The panther against the nice man. Gogarty reaches down carelessly beh Baby.

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Hello, George, me boyo! A funny expression comes over his face as he goes on patt begins to suspect this isn't a dog, because dogs don't pu his courage and looks around, then springs to his feet wi inarticulate cry and rushes out of the stable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gogarty has the fish course set out on a silver tray passing the kitchen door as Gogarty bursts in and sends t Mrs. Gogarty stares at him indignantly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Blast you, Gogarty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROUP SHOT. As David and George enter there is a terrific scene. David, without a word of explanation about his abs his seat and fixes his eyes on George.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (ringing the bell violently) What was that? Hannah! Hannah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT -- Hannah and Gogarty.

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Hannah, this is no time for personalities. Where's my gun

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Gun? What would you be wanting with a gun?

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Don't be asking questions in a crisis! Where's my gun?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GOGARTY
dialogues.text: It's where you left it -- in your room under the bed, the thought you heard a burglar. What do you want it for now?

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: A cat it was! (gesturing) That big! With eyes like balls of fire! The ringing of the dining room bell is heard off-scene, a Elizabeth's voice.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hannah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. Mrs. Gogarty appears in the pantry doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What was all that banging about out there?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GOGARTY
dialogues.text: That was Gogarty, ma'am. Gogarty's face appears in the doorway behind her.

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: I saw a cat! I saw a cat as big as a cow, Mrs. Random! It and breathed in my face!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GOGARTY
dialogues.text: That's what I said, ma'am. Susan and David freeze and lean forward. For the first ti his gaze from George.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What -- did -- you -- say -- you -- saw?

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: A cat -- with eyes like balls of fire.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Gogarty, you've been drinking again!

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: Nary a drop have I had, Mrs. Random, as I live an' breath what's needed and a man to wield it -- an' Gogarty's the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gogarty pushes Gogarty back through the door and clo

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (to ease the social tension; laughing nervously I saw a tiger once -- in Abyssinia.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: (rising as one) Excuse me! Applegate, checked in mid-sentence, stares open-mouthed a figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's too much the meal?

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: No, no, Elizabeth, I --

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Good! Hannah, serve the 143 INT. VANCE STABLE -— Susan and David rush in.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Baby! BABY!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Now don't lose your head

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (insanely) Don't lose my what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don't lose your head!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (clasping her head frant. I haven't lost my head!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (shaking her) Collect yourself, Susan! hysteria. Stop shaking!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I -- I'm not -- s-shakin to expect -- but would you mind staying through er -- I was planning to. next course!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The stall is empty. , Susan! Don't lose your head! ically) I haven't! Nothing is to be gained by uncontrolled g. You -- you're -- s-shaking me. He drops his hands. For the first time Susan has met her willing to turn to David for a solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gogarty enters from the pantry with a platter of roa

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (helping herself) One reason why I'd like to go on this expedition, Horace, would make Drusilla Voorhies green with jealousy. She's a about her experiences -- but the only primitive life she' when she was living with that fat tenor what's-his-name.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Oh! Was he -- primitive? Susan enters and slides into her seat behind Mrs. Gogarty

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Squab.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Ten years, off and on, I've lived with Drusilla -- and I' her stop acting. She can't forget that she once sang at L neglects to mention that it cost her third husband ten th A voice like a crow -- and I can't give a party that she after dinner!

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Elizabeth, I shouldn't live with her.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: But, Horace, she's my dearest friend.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (choking on his food) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And now that she has that moth-eaten cheetah she's insuff

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Oh. A cheetah. You mean -- (making his four fingers walk on the tablecloth)  a cheetah?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh, it's perfectly safe. Its teeth are all gone. But it w follow her -- and that's all she wants. Attention! That's Paris. I will not be put in the shade by that woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David at telephone in an agitated state.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listen! It doesn't matter what my name is. I -- saw -- a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- Zoo official in uniform, at phone.

dialogues.speaker: ZOO OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard you. You saw a panther. (drily) In Connecticut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, Applegate, Aunt Elizabeth at table. Susan has fini She is prattling to cover David's telephoning.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I know just how you feel, Aunt Elizabeth, about the Voorh Cheetahs are nasty things to have around the house. Any b lot of bother.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (brusquely) Nothing of the kind! I'm going to have a panther. Mark's Brazil.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (stunned) A panther?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (emphatically) I'm not going to have Drusilla lording it over me any lon cheetah. Mark cabled me that he had the panther. I can't hasn't arrived. Maybe he's training it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (faintly) Excuse me. (staggers from the room in search of David)

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Has she ever been clawed by a panther?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is just hanging up the telephone receiver as Susan room, skids on the rug and falls at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Don't call the Zoo! Don't call the Zoo, David!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've called the Zoo. It's all fixed!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Call them back and unfix it! Don't ask questions! Call th

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I will not! I told the Zoo they could have the panther if

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You gave him Baby! You gave away my life's happiness -- m trust in me! You gave away my inheritance!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've had enough! I quit!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (thrusting receiver at him) You can't quit!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You told me the only thing standing between you and a mil that panther. Well -- now it's gone!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (wailing) But, David, everything's changed. I just found out that p to Aunt Elizabeth! (dancing in a frenzy) I'll explain later! Call them back and tell them you were

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've just spent fifteen minutes convincing them that I di They won't believe me!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (wrenching receiver from him) I'll tell them you're a drug addict -- that you're always

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (wrenching receiver back) You'll do nothing of the sort! (starts to dial)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Elizabeth and Major Applegate have reached the desse

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'd like to finance your expedition, Horace -- but there be said for furthering science. Without science we wouldn surgery and the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without science, Elizabeth, we'd be free of this complica civilization. The primitive life is the richer life. Men untrammeled -- Think of it!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I also have to think of the responsibility of giving away I'd like to have my name in the Museum. But before I make must talk to this young Dr. Huxley I've heard so much abo able to decide between you -- the Museum -- and Susan.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: I had my heart set on showing you the jungle, Elizabeth. vast mysterious silence vibrant with life -- strange crie There is a strange cry in the night, which we know is Bab don't. They listen. George gets up and goes to the window

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Horace?

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: A loon! (resuming his rhapsody Once you got the jungle in your blood, Elizabeth, I would keep you out of it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I'd have to come out every now and then for a permanent.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Picture bathing in a cool, limpid stream ---- Again Baby screams. George drops his paws from the window

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUEST BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: David hangs up the receiver, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There's nobody there. The night watchman says they've all panther hunting.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Then there's only one thing to do, David. We must catch do! What is the best thing to take when you're going to c

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (mad) A bigger panther!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Elizabeth and Major Applegate are at coffee as Susan enter. David starts walking around the table, peering und George.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (agitated) George! Where's George?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I don't know! What does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Matter?... Susan, you've lost George again!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Why this morbid interest in George?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He has my intercostal clavicle!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh, Horace, take him away!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Don't be angry with David, Auntie. He's just overwrought.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I wish he'd go somewhere else and be overwrought! They are diverted by the sudden outcry of the panther. Su look at each other.

The place is lousy with panthers!

dialogues.text: Oh, Susan, do stop making a fool of yourself!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN

dialogues.text: Didn't come with me. (injured) After all I've gone through for you, that you can't come simple thing like helping me find a panther -- I think it shabby! I'd rather -- if you don't mind -- go on alone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, very well. He sits down on a log and lights a cigarette. Susan pushe the brush. Her blind crashing is heard. There is a terrif silence. David listens as a gurgling cry rises to a wail. out his cigarette and starts in the direction of the wail

dialogues.text: Susan crying and rolling over as she tries to extricate h mass of vines. David stalks in. Once more he lifts her to that she is no longer the managing Susan his tenderness c fore. He still knows that she is a menace but he realizes something soft and feminine in his arms.

dialogues.text: Susan, your natural instinct for being wrong astounds me. rather be with you wrong than with anyone else right.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Da-vid!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (her mouth up) I d-don't c-care. David is gradually growing less interested in mopping her kissing it. He struggles manfully against the impulse but face higher. Just as he is about to kiss her there is the scream of a panther, only a few yards away. David jumps a

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But it's Baby!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Of course it is. What of it? (opens her eyes; he is gone) Oh, blast Baby! I'll make him pay for this! She starts after David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good Baby. Nice Baby. (George growls; David looks at the dog grimly I'll deal with you later. (reaches toward Susan, behind him)  Quick -- give me that rope!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I -- T lost it! David, in dull fury, stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All right. You take him home!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Come, Baby. Come home with Susan. Come, darling. Come, sw Baby, to her astonishment, begins following her. CAMERA M

dialogues.text: Susan and David under the treed panther. Susan is singing Can't Give You Anything But Love, Baby’. George sits besi feeling for music beginning to stir. David is picking up wherever he can find a word that he knows. George, caught of the thing, lifts his muzzle and croons in unison -- he chorus rises Baby lifts his voice in his own version.

dialogues.text: Susan! Mr. Bone! Are you all right?

dialogues.text: (eyeing Susan and David with suspicion) Now if Aloysius Gogarty had been wielding that gun you'd panther.

dialogues.text: You, sir -- as everybody except you and Miss Vance seem t crazy. (turns to Susan) I forbid you to go further with this man. The panther is treacherous of animals. I will continue the hunt, but you

dialogues.text: (in an undertone, twitching at his sleeve) It's just as well. He couldn't be any crazier than she i

dialogues.text: Susan, don't you think that if we stopped trying to keep secret from everybody there might be less confusion and m getting the panther?

dialogues.text: Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I do. (turns to Applegate) You may have heard, sir, that Mrs. Random was expecting a Brazil -- a pet panther. (points off) That is the panther.

dialogues.text: I quit! Yes, sir, be gob, I quit! Aloysius Gogarty is goi panther.

dialogues.text: I don't believe it!

dialogues.text: I know it's hard to believe, but I can explain it. Gogarty sneers again and looks up at the stars.

dialogues.text: (to Applegate) If I told Aunt Elizabeth that you shot at her panther, wh you'd get with your old expedition? Applegate, whipsawed, looks from one to the other.

dialogues.text: The only thing to do, Susan, is to explain things. (to Applegate) It all started this morning when Susan telephoned me...

dialogues.text: Lady, I'm trying to tell you we're from the Zoo. We had a It came from here. This house!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: But there must be some mistake. The panther hasn't come y

dialogues.text: Do you expect it to walk up -- and in?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Naturally not! I expect to receive a notice from the Frei first! The Zoo Official looks at her and backs away.

dialogues.speaker: ZOO OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: (pacifyingly) Yes, lady. Don't get excited. Sure, you'll have a notice Office.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Obviously, my good man, what you're looking for is a loon (and she slams the door)

dialogues.speaker: ZOO OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: (yelling back)  I don't have to look any farther!

dialogues.speaker: AT OPEN CAR
dialogues.text: as the Zoo Official comes back to his friends.

dialogues.speaker: ZOO OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Screwy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Well, sir, that's the story. We had him until you fired. to find him again.

dialogues.text: Oh, absolutely!

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: (twitching at Applegate's sleeve) I -- I patted him. I reached my hand out and patted him r back. He's gentle as a kitten.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: (pointing) he looks around uncertainly) .. Which way did he go?  That way.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: He's trying to throw us off. And he starts off in the opposite direction, followed by suddenly very brave. Applegate stops and raises his finge to Susan and David.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: Don't forget now! If you get lost, halloo! He vanishes. Susan and David have no choice but to take t proper direction. They start out.

dialogues.text: Applegate and Gogarty emerge from the bushes. Gogarty is Applegate peers off intently to left. Gogarty taps him on and points off to right.

dialogues.text: The bad panther stalking along in the clear moonlight.

dialogues.text: There is nothing -- to be worried about. You -- just stan take care of this.

dialogues.text: (doubt fully) I just remembered an errand Miss Susan wanted me to do. M be gettin' about it.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: You -- say you -- patted -- this beast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- in a manner of speaking I -- yes, I patted him -- speaking. Yes, I patted him. But sometimes the dispositio things are subject to -- a quick change. Applegate moves out of scene as Gogarty stands poised for draws a bottle from his hip pocket and takes a healthy dr

At this po become only an impediment to Gogarty, whose urgency to pe errand has been too much for him. He is loping without re Applegate or Applegate's safety, in the direction of the of trees. Applegate overhauls him. Gogarty trips and fall and the gun goes off. Applegate skids into Gogarty, grabs pumps another shell into it, levels the gun in the direct he has run.

dialogues.text: on Susan and David trudging along country road.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: You know, David -- I've been trying to figure out why you back there. You almost did.

dialogues.text: Susan, I think we won't discuss that.

dialogues.text: But, David, there's -- nothing really wrong in kissing a it's just that you have to get a point of view about it. instance, you were to touch my face -- this way -- (reaches out and pats him) -- there wouldn't be anything wrong about that, would the even do it accidentally, couldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I couldn't kiss you accidentally, Susan. If I kissed you quite deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (her brand of logic) Well -- there wouldn't be anything wrong in your reachin touching my cheek deliberately, would there?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. I suppose there wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Then why would it be wrong for you to kiss me, deliberate much different, really -- is it, David?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. It's quite different.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like -- I'd like -- to try it and see -- why it don't see any difference.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Susan, I am an engaged man. If I hadn't lost my fossil, I married man.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh, I wouldn't kiss a married man. She has edged up to him and is walking so close that she him as she stares up hungrily into his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't intend to kiss you, Susan. You might as well put pretty little head. I intend to go back to New York and b They are passing a country house, when a low growl is hea and stare off.

dialogues.text: WHAT THEY SEE: Baby outlined against the sky, on the vera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, from Susan's angle. He hangs his paws over the edge roof contentedly.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: "I can't give you anything but love, Baa-by. That's the only thing I've plenty of, Baa-by. Etc."

dialogues.text: What are you doing, may I ask?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Singing.

dialogues.text: I'm not going to bandy words with you at this time of nig

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: There's a panther on your roof and it's my panther and I' him. To get him, I have to sing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Digby and his wife.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DIGBY
dialogues.text: There is nothing on my roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT of Susan.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: There is! Come out and look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Digby and his wife. Her face softens.

dialogues.text: George and David playing "Follow the Leader." George goe porch. David, wary, goes to other side and waits, ready t George, who is no fool, comes out of the same opening and a teasing trot. David follows him.

dialogues.text: The bang of the door frightens Baby and he leaps lightly

dialogues.text: He went that way!

dialogues.speaker: DR. DIGBY
dialogues.text: Hush, hush, it's all right.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (struggling) You've frightened him away and now I'll never see him aga

dialogues.text: See? He's still there. See him?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: He's not! Let go of my arm! Let go!

dialogues.text: He'll come back, don't worry. Now you tell me where you l know?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Of course I know! That's not the point. I have to get my you help me?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DIGBY
dialogues.text: I certainly will. He draws her firmly up the steps, Susan resisting manfull

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go! You don't realize that there's a million dollars

dialogues.speaker: DR. DIGBY
dialogues.text: You'll get it. I have it right in here -- all in one-doll

dialogues.text: WHAT HE SEES: From his angle, as Digby opens the door and inside.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN

dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT -- David, as he puts his hand over his eyes. T straw. Now they really are in the toils.

dialogues.text: on Applegate and Gogarty. Gogarty by now has imbibed, sh freely. His sense of direction has never been good. It is drowned. He is in a fogged and befuddled state. Applegate to ask directions, is thrown for a loss by Joe's question vaguely.

dialogues.text: Why -- why -- how did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Joe leans out further, nettled.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't joke, buddy. Our jobs depend on this. We had a kill this truck and he got away.

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: (thickly, peering at Joe) You mean -- he wasn't gentle as a kitten?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I mean there is a guy almost dying in a hospital right no clawed by him.

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: I can tell you where to find him. I saw him right over -- (begins pointing around in various directions and can't r right one because he is lost and has been for some time) right over -- over -- No, it wasn't there -- it was -- (pointing in another direction) No, it wasn't. (puts it squarely up to them) Do you know where I am?

dialogues.text: (twitching at his sleeve) I think we're still in Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically, to Mac and Joe) You see -- we've sort of -- lost our sense of direction. Mac and Joe look at each other blankly.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Another one!

dialogues.speaker: APPLEGATE
dialogues.text: (to Gogarty) Well -- there's only one thing -- to do. (cups his hands and bawls) Halloooo!

dialogues.speaker: GOGARTY
dialogues.text: (cups his hands and bawls) Halloooo! Applegate and Gogarty are standing back to back, hallooin

dialogues.text: Everybody in Connecticut is nuts! Joe slaps the truck in gear and it moves on out of scene. light vanishes, we hear our duet of halloos.

dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT Mrs. Digby, now in a wrapper, on the telephone

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DIGBY
dialogues.text: Well, Constable, it's quite obvious that the girl is dera is working on her now -- mental cases are his specialty. must find her people. I wish you'd come right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Digby has Susan in a chair under a strong light and i of a psychiatric examination.

dialogues.text: But the panther is really the young man. You must underst dear young lady.

dialogues.text: Well, let's approach it from a different angle. One key t subconscious is association. When I say a word I want you quickly the first thing that comes into your head. You un

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: George!

dialogues.speaker: DR. DIGBY
dialogues.text: (growing more frantic) George!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Baby!

dialogues.speaker: DR. DIGBY
dialogues.text: Baby!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: George!

dialogues.text: George!

dialogues.text: Don't you think you should go to a sanitorium for a nice

dialogues.text: (wearily) George!
